Package space.sunqian.common

Class Fs

java.lang.Object
space.sunqian.common.Fs
public class Fs extends Object
The core utility class of this library, provides support methods for Object, such as equals and hashCode. And many methods to improve language convenience, such as nonnull, uncheck. And shortcuts to other commonly used methods in this lib, such as list(Object[]), copyProperties(Object, Object, Option[]), convert(Object, Class, Option[]), etc.

    • as

      public static <T> T as(@Nullable @Nullable Object obj)
      Casts and returns the given object as the specified type T. This method is equivalent to: 
      
 return (T) obj;
      Type Parameters:
      T - the specified type
      Parameters:
      obj - the given object
      Returns:
      the given object as the specified type T

    • asNonnull

      @Nonnull public static <T> T asNonnull(@Nullable T obj)
      Directly returns the given object itself. The given object is annotated by Nullable, but the return value is annotated by Nonnull. This method is used to suppress some IDE or compilation warnings.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the given object
      Parameters:
      obj - the given object
      Returns:
      the given object itself

    • nonnull

      public static <T> T nonnull(@Nullable T obj, T defaultValue)
      Returns the default value if the given object is null, or the given object itself if it is not null. This method is equivalent to: 
      
 return obj == null ? defaultValue : obj;

      Note this method does not guarantee that the returned value must be nonnull.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the returned value
      Parameters:
      obj - the given object
      defaultValue - the default value
      Returns:
      the default value if the given object is null, or the given object itself if it is not null

    • nonnull

      public static <T> T nonnull(@Nullable T obj, Supplier<? extends T> supplier)
      Returns the value computed from the specified supplier if the given object is null, or the given object itself if it is not null. This method is equivalent to: 
      
 return obj == null ? supplier.get() : obj;

      Note this method does not guarantee that the returned value must be nonnull.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the returned value
      Parameters:
      obj - the given object
      supplier - the specified supplier
      Returns:
      the value computed from the specified supplier if the given object is null, or the given object itself if it is not null

    • uncheck

      public static void uncheck(@Nonnull @Nonnull VoidCallable action, @Nonnull @Nonnull Function<? super @Nonnull Exception,? extends @Nonnull RuntimeException> unchecked)
      Runs the given action and wraps any exception into an unchecked exception, the unchecked exception is generated by the given unchecked exception generator. The logic as follows: 
      
 try {
     action.call();
 } catch (Exception e) {
     throw unchecked.apply(e);
 }
      Parameters:
      action - the given action
      unchecked - the given unchecked exception generator

    • uncheck

      public static <T> T uncheck(@Nonnull @Nonnull Callable<T> action, @Nonnull @Nonnull Function<? super @Nonnull Exception,? extends @Nonnull RuntimeException> unchecked)
      Runs the given action and wraps any exception into an unchecked exception, the unchecked exception is generated by the given unchecked exception generator. The logic as follows: 
      
 try {
     return action.call();
 } catch (Exception e) {
     throw unchecked.apply(e);
 }
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      action - the given action
      unchecked - the given unchecked exception generator
      Returns:
      the result of the given action

    • uncheck

      public static void uncheck(@Nonnull @Nonnull VoidCallable action)
      Runs the given action and ignores any exception thrown by the action. The logic as follows: 
      
 try {
     action.call();
 } catch (Exception ignored) {
 }
      Parameters:
      action - the given action

    • call

      public static <T> T call(@Nonnull @Nonnull Callable<T> action, T defaultValue)
      Calls the given action and returns the result. If any exception is thrown, returns the default value. The logic as follows: 
      
 try {
     return action.call();
 } catch (Exception e) {
     return defaultValue;
 }
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      action - the given action
      defaultValue - the default value
      Returns:
      the result of the given action, or the default value if any exception is thrown

    • call

      public static <T> Ret<T> call(@Nonnull @Nonnull Callable<T> action)
      Calls the given action and returns the result wrapped by Ret. The logic as follows: 
      
 try {
     T ret = action.call();
     return Ret.of(ret);
 } catch (Throwable e) {
     return Ret.of(e);
 }
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the result
      Parameters:
      action - the given action
      Returns:
      the result of the given action wrapped by Ret

    • until

      public static void until(@Nonnull @Nonnull BooleanCallable task) throws AwaitingException
      Executes the given task until it returns true or throws an exception. The original exception will be wrapped by AwaitingException then thrown, using Throwable.getCause() can get the original exception. The logic of this method is as follows: 
      
 try {
     while (true) {
         if (task.call()) {
             return;
         }
     }
 } catch (Exception e) {
     throw new AwaitingException(e);
 }

      Note this method may cause high CPU usage. When the task determines to return false, consider adding some measures (such as sleep the current thread in a very short time) to avoid it.

      Parameters:
      task - the given task to be executed
      Throws:
      AwaitingException - if an error occurs while awaiting

    • equals

      public static boolean equals(@Nullable @Nullable Object a, @Nullable @Nullable Object b)
      Returns whether the given objects are equal. If the given objects are arrays, uses Arrays.equals or Arrays.deepEquals(Object[], Object[]) if necessary.

      This method is equivalent to (equalsWith(Object, Object, boolean, boolean)): equalsWith(a, b, true, true).

      Parameters:
      a - the given object a
      b - the given object b
      Returns:
      whether the given objects are equal

    • equalsAll

      public static boolean equalsAll(@Nullable @Nullable Object @Nonnull ... objects)
      Returns whether the given objects are equal each other by equals(Object, Object).
      Parameters:
      objects - the given objects
      Returns:
      whether the given objects are equal

    • equalsWith

      public static boolean equalsWith(@Nullable @Nullable Object a, @Nullable @Nullable Object b, boolean arrayEquals, boolean deep)
      Returns whether the given objects are equal. This method follows the following logic:
      • If a == b, returns true;
      • If the arrayEquals is true:
        • If the deep is true, uses Arrays.deepEquals(Object[], Object[]) for them. Otherwise, uses Arrays.equals.
      • Returns Objects.equals(Object, Object) otherwise.
      Parameters:
      a - the given object a
      b - the given object b
      arrayEquals - the arrayEquals option
      deep - the deep option
      Returns:
      whether the given objects are equal

    • hashCode

      public static int hashCode(@Nullable @Nullable Object obj)
      Returns the hashcode of the given object. If the given object is array, uses Arrays.hashCode or Arrays.deepHashCode(Object[]) if necessary.

      This method is equivalent to (hashWith(Object, boolean, boolean)): hashWith(obj, true, true).

      Parameters:
      obj - the given object
      Returns:
      the hashcode of the given object

    • hashAll

      public static int hashAll(@Nullable @Nullable Object @Nonnull ... objs)
      Returns the hashcode of the given objects via Arrays.deepHashCode(Object[]).
      Parameters:
      objs - the given objects
      Returns:
      the hashcode of the given objects via Arrays.deepHashCode(Object[])

    • hashWith

      public static int hashWith(@Nullable @Nullable Object obj, boolean arrayHash, boolean deep)
      Returns the hashcode of the given object. This method follows the following logic:
      • If the given object is not an array, returns Objects.hashCode(Object).
      • If the arrayHash is true:
        • If the deep is true, uses Arrays.deepHashCode(Object[]) for them. Otherwise, uses Arrays.hashCode.
      • Returns Objects.hashCode(Object) otherwise.
      Parameters:
      obj - the given object
      arrayHash - the arrayHash option
      deep - the deep option
      Returns:
      the hashcode of the given object

    • hashId

      public static int hashId(@Nullable @Nullable Object obj)
      Returns the identity hashcode of the given object, this method is equivalent to System.identityHashCode(Object).
      Parameters:
      obj - the given object
      Returns:
      the identity hashcode of the given object

    • copyProperties

      public static void copyProperties(@Nonnull @Nonnull Object src, @Nonnull @Nonnull Object dst, @Nonnull @Nonnull Option<?,?> @Nonnull ... options) throws ObjectConvertException
      Copy properties from the given source object to the given destination object. The object can be a Map or a non-map object which can be parsed to ObjectSchema.

      The options parameter can be empty, in which case the default behavior will be used, or built-in options in ConvertOption or other custom options for custom implementations.

      This method is a shortcut to the DataMapper.copyProperties(Object, Object, Option[]).

      Parameters:
      src - the given source object
      dst - the given destination object
      options - the options for copying properties
      Throws:
      ObjectConvertException - if an error occurs during copying properties
      See Also:
      • DataMapper

    • copyProperties

      public static void copyProperties(@Nonnull @Nonnull Object src, @Nonnull @Nonnull Object dst, @Nonnull @Nonnull ObjectConverter converter, @Nonnull @Nonnull Option<?,?> @Nonnull ... options) throws ObjectConvertException
      Copy properties from the given source object to the given destination object. The object can be a Map or a non-map object which can be parsed to ObjectSchema.

      The options parameter can be empty, in which case the default behavior will be used, or built-in options in ConvertOption or other custom options for custom implementations.

      This method is a shortcut to the DataMapper.copyProperties(Object, Object, ObjectConverter, Option[]).

      Parameters:
      src - the given source object
      dst - the given destination object
      converter - the converter for converting values of the properties if needed
      options - the options for copying properties
      Throws:
      ObjectConvertException - if an error occurs during copying properties
      See Also:
      • DataMapper

      public static <T> T convert(@Nullable @Nullable Object src, @Nonnull @Nonnull Class<? extends T> target, @Nonnull @Nonnull Option<?,?> @Nonnull ... options) throws UnsupportedObjectConvertException, ObjectConvertException
      Converts the given source object from the specified type to the target type.

      The options parameter can be empty, in which case the default behavior will be used, or built-in options in ConvertOption or other custom options for custom implementations.

      This method is a shortcut to the ObjectConverter.convert(Object, Class, Option[]).

      Type Parameters:
      T - the target type
      Parameters:
      src - the given source object
      target - the specified type of the target object
      options - the other conversion options
      Returns:
      the converted object, null is permitted
      Throws:
      UnsupportedObjectConvertException - if the conversion from the specified type to the target type is not supported
      ObjectConvertException - if the conversion failed
      See Also:
      • ObjectConverter

    • list

      @SafeVarargs @Nonnull @Immutable public static <T> @Nonnull @Immutable List<T> list(T @Nonnull @RetainedParam ... array)
      Returns an immutable list backed by the given array. The returned list is immutable but the backing array is not, changes to the backing array "write through" to the returned list. The returned list is serializable and implements RandomAccess.

      This method is a shortcut to the ListKit.list(Object[]).

      Type Parameters:
      T - the component type
      Parameters:
      array - the given array
      Returns:
      an immutable list backed by the given array
      See Also:
      • ListKit

    • set

      @SafeVarargs @Nonnull @Immutable public static <T> @Nonnull @Immutable Set<T> set(T @Nonnull ... array)
      Returns a new immutable set of which content is added from the given array. The content of the set is added in array order, and the duplicate elements will be ignored. The behavior of this method is equivalent to: 
      
 return Collections.unmodifiableSet(linkedHashSet(array));

      This method is a shortcut to the SetKit.set(Object[]).

      Type Parameters:
      T - the component type
      Parameters:
      array - the given array
      Returns:
      a new immutable set of which content is added from the given array
      See Also:
      • SetKit

    • map

      @Nonnull @Immutable public static <K, V> @Nonnull @Immutable Map<K,V> map(Object @Nonnull ... array)
      Returns a new immutable map of which content is added from the given array.

      Every two elements of the array form a key-value pair, that means, the array[0] and array[1] will be the first key-value pair, the array[2] and array[3] will be the second key-value pair, and so on. If the length of the array is odd and the last key cannot match the value, then the last pair will be the key-null pair to put.

      The behavior of this method is equivalent to: 

      
  return Collections.unmodifiableMap(linkedHashMap(array));

      This method is a shortcut to the MapKit.map(Object[]).

      Type Parameters:
      K - the key type
      V - the value type
      Parameters:
      array - the given array
      Returns:
      a new HashMap initialing with the given array
      See Also:
      • MapKit

    • hashMap

      @Nonnull public static <K, V> @Nonnull HashMap<K,V> hashMap(Object @Nonnull ... array)
      Returns a new HashMap initialing with the given array.

      Every two elements of the array form a key-value pair, that means, the array[0] and array[1] will be the first key-value pair, the array[2] and array[3] will be the second key-value pair, and so on. If the length of the array is odd and the last key cannot match the value, then the last pair will be the key-null pair to put.

      This method is a shortcut to the MapKit.hashMap(Object[]).

      Type Parameters:
      K - the key type
      V - the value type
      Parameters:
      array - the given array
      Returns:
      a new HashMap initialing with the given array
      See Also:
      • MapKit

    • linkedHashMap

      @Nonnull public static <K, V> @Nonnull LinkedHashMap<K,V> linkedHashMap(Object @Nonnull ... array)
      Returns a new LinkedHashMap initialing with the given array

      Every two elements of the array form a key-value pair, that means, the array[0] and array[1] will be the first key-value pair, the array[2] and array[3] will be the second key-value pair, and so on. If the length of the array is odd and the last key cannot match the value, then the last pair will be the key-null pair to put.

      This method is a shortcut to the MapKit.linkedHashMap(Object[]).

      Type Parameters:
      K - the key type
      V - the value type
      Parameters:
      array - the given array
      Returns:
      a new HashMap initialing with the given array
      See Also:
      • MapKit

    • sleep

      Throws:
